title.narrative: Facilitating the provision of lifesaving Child Protection services to extremely vulnerable children in East and West Mosul

description.narrative:
The proposed project will provide support to newly displaced IDP children and adolescents boys and girls (aged 6-17 years) fleeing conflict affected areas with Child protection intervention in line with Child protection Cluster’s minimum assistance for Child protection response package outlined in the 2017 HRP. Through its Child protection intervention services, War Child UK (WCUK) will provide an age appropriate and gender sensitive child protection activities for 2,400 boys and girls and 1,744 adults from the displaced and host community in East and West Mosul. The project will primarily target newly-retaken areas with large concentrations of IDPs from Mosul in the Hamam Al-Aleem 1 camp, as well as 6 neighborhoods in Mosul city (Qahira, Miharabeen, Qadissya, Masarif, Elam and Muthana). WCUK prioritized the Ninewah governorate as planning documents predict that the governorate is likely to receive a considerable portion of IDP's fleeing Mosul and its surrounding areas. However, as the context is fluid and subject to several external variables, the exact location selection is flexible within these locations. The WC child protection services provided will increase access to PSS, PFA as well as essential case management services including referrals. These activities will be implemented through 3 mobile teams where one team will cover Western Mosul and 2 teams will cover Eastern Mosul. The mobile teams will first enter the school to conduct PSS which will serve as an entry point to working with children and selecting the most vulnerable. Of the 2,100 reached through PSS, the psychologist and the mobile teams will assess the most vulnerable and provide 500 individuals with specialized support through PFA and referrals. We are estimating that of these 500, 300 will require sustained case-management support. The project will also train 125 staff (both CP and non-CP) on essential CP issues such as CPiE, case-management, and PFA. This will be essential in ensuring that the children will receive the needed services from staff who are trained and who are aware the vulnerability of the children they work with.
As WCUK is one of the key agencies responding to CP and educational needs in Iraq, WCUK's child protection response has been developed in close consultation with the respective clusters and has framed this intervention in line with the Child protection Cluster Strategy. With over 12 years implementation experience in Iraq WCUK is familiar with the context and is accustomed to implementing projects in challenging environments, including the Syria response. WCUK recently implemented a similar project in Anbar which provided services for IDPs from Ramadi and Falluja. WCUK will draw upon lessons learned in the Anbar intervention to guide its Mosul response as well as sector specific best practice and minimum standards.
